Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
This Noyce project at the College of Mount Saint Vincent (CMSV) supports 16 undergraduate science or math majors who elect to pursue a teaching career. This institution is located in New York City and has a history of excellence in serving Hispanic and other minority and low-income students. The intellectual merit derives not only from leveraging existing academic programs and student support resources but also from developing two new components of STEM/Teacher Education program at the college. Specifically, summer courses and a new 4-year pathway for STEM/TE transfer students are being added. Plans are in place to give students early exposure to teaching, strategies for working in high-need schools, mentoring by master teachers and college faculty, professional development workshops, research opportunities in science, and educational action research. Structured, supervised, and supported field experiences, as well as in-depth exposure to the inner workings of high-need schools helps Noyce scholars transition into teaching and persist in the profession.

This project has several broader impacts. First, the project increases the number of students from traditionally underrepresented groups that enter STEM teaching fields. The College's attention to the values of diversity, inclusion, and experiential/reflective learning have the potential to create a model that benefits other programs serving highly diverse student populations. Second, changes and improvements made to the teacher education program as a result of this project impact many more than just the 16 Noyce scholarship recipients. Third, development of a seamless, 4-year STEM/TE pathway should enable many more students transferring from community colleges to complete a STEM degree with teacher certification in the shortest possible time. The plan is to sustain this program so that through time, many STEM majors become highly trained and inspirational mathematics and science teachers to diverse students in New York's high-needs schools. Plans are in place to document and share best practices and lessons learned with other institutions with similar characteristics via conferences and pedagogical publications.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The College of Mount Saint Vincent is an ethnically-diverse private college that serves traditionally under-represented students in the New York City area. The Robert Noyce Teacher Scholarship Program provided tuition assistance to math or Biology majors enrolled in the Dual Adolescent Certification program. As diversity, inclusion, collaborative preparation and experiential/reflective learning define the framework of the Teacher Education program, the various experiences in which the Noyce Scholars participated provided many opportunities for Scholars to deepen their understanding of these educational constructs. Such experiences include but are not limited to the Mentorship program and Teacher-in-Residence Program. 

 Central to the professional support provided to the Scholars was a strong mentorship program whereby a Noyce Scholar was paired with a practicing teacher (alumnus of the College) who provided an essential bridge between theory and practice. The mentors proved to be strong role models for the Noyce Scholars. Mentors and Scholars met bimonthly to discuss classroom management, specific teaching/learning strategies, effective use of technology and content specific pedagogy. This support was further supplemented by the Teacher -in -Residence program. Periodic meetings between Noyce Scholars and master science and mathematics teachers from high-need schools were conducted and addressed best practices and strategies for teaching in high-need schools.  Both the mentorship and Teacher- in- Residence Program provided a  pathway for Noyce Scholars to learn more  about the expectations, challenges, and proven strategies and practices. Additionally, these experiences provided an opportunity for Noyce Scholars to discuss their experiences in the varied field experiences seeking advice and guidance from effective educators working in high needs schools.

 An outgrowth of the Noyce Teacher Scholarship Program is a Pay it Forward Mentorship Program.  It originated with the assistance of two Noyce Scholars who provided informal support to students in the education program, but has grown to include alumni from the various education programs who provide workshops to the education program. The goal is to develop an online support network for current education students whereby alumni of the program would provide virtual workshops and chat sessions.

 Overall, the Noyce Teacher Scholarship program enhanced the learning and professional opportunities of the Noyce Scholars and provided various layers of support both during the completion of their education at the College and in the initial years of teaching.
